He was being called 'gay'."<ref name="TELDAM">{{Cite news|last=Steele|first=John|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1377304/Damilolas-father-attacks-loss-of-values.html|title=Damilola's father attacks loss of values|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|date=19 June 2001|location=London}}</ref> In the New Statesman two years later, when there had still been no convictions for the crime, Peter Tatchell, gay human rights campaigner, said, "In the days leading up to his murder in south London in November 2000, he was subjected to vicious homophobic abuse and assaults,"<ref name="NSDAM">{{Cite journal|last=Tatchell|first=Peter|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/200301130014|title=A victim of homophobia?|journal=New Statesman|date=13 Jan 2003}}</ref> and asked why the authorities had ignored this before and after his death. * Geoffrey Windsor, 57, in south London died in June 2002 from head injuries at Beaulieu Heights, a well-known gay cruising area, after he was beaten and robbed. The police said the murder was motivated by homophobia.<ref name="LONUNS1" /> A review of this and similar cases in the area highlighted poor policing due to institutional homophobia within the police, particularly in not taking previous attacks in the area more seriously.<ref name="LONUNS3" /> * [[Lauren Harries]], a trans woman and British media personality, was attacked in July 2005 along with her father and brother in their home in [[Cardiff]] by eight youths who shouted the word "tranny" while beating their victims. One youth pleaded guilty to inflicting grievous bodily harm and was sentenced to two years probation; his accomplices were not formally identified or charged.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/4216786.stm|publisher=BBC News|title=Transsexual and family attacked|date=5 September 2005|accessdate=9 April 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/tm_objectid=16149951&method=full&siteid=50082&headline=youth-who-attacked-transsexual-spared-jail--name_page.html |title=Youth who attacked transsexual spared jail |publisher=WalesOnline |date=Sep 19, 2005 |accessdate=2010-07-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090217070221/http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/tm_objectid%3D16149951%26method%3Dfull%26siteid%3D50082%26headline%3Dyouth-who-attacked-transsexual-spared-jail--name_page.html |archivedate=2009-02-17 |df= }}</ref> * [[Jody Dobrowski]] was beaten to death on 14 October 2005 on Clapham Common in London by two men who perceived him as being gay; Dobrowski was beaten so badly he had to be identified by his fingerprints. Thomas Pickford and Scott Walker were given life sentences in what was described as a 'homophobic murder' in June 2006.<ref name="DOB">{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/london/5087286.stm|title=Men jailed for gay barman murder|publisher=BBC News|date=16 June 2006}}</ref> This was the first prosecution in England and Wales where Section 146 of the Criminal Justice Act 2003 was used in sentencing the killers; this enabled the courts to impose a tougher sentence for offenses motivated or aggravated by the victim's sexual orientation, in this case a minimum of 30 years in prison.<ref name="SOBCJA">{{Cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/crime/article717120.ece|title=Two face 30 years in jail for homophobic murder|publisher=[[The Times]]|date=13 May 2006|location=London|first1=Roland|last1=Watson|first2=Miles|last2=Costello|first3=Sam|last3=Fleming}}</ref> * Rt Rev Dr Barry Rathbone, an openly gay priest, was attacked in April 2006. He was sitting in a park in Bournemouth, Dorset when Martin Powell and his girlfriend approached and spoke to him. Dr Rathbone informed them that it was a cruising area, then Powell produced a {{convert|3|ft|m|adj=mid|-long}} metal baseball bat, called him a 'queer', and started to hit him, causing multiple injuries. Powell was subsequently jailed after plea bargaining down from attempted murder to assault occasioning serious bodily harm with intent and served 2 1/2 years in total. Dr Rathbone publicly forgave Powell in an interview with the BBC<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/dorset/4895796.stm|title=Man jailed for priest attack | work=BBC News | date=April 10, 2006}}</ref> * [[Michael Causer]], 18, was attacked by a group of men on 25 July 2008 at a party in [[Liverpool]], and died from his injuries. It is alleged that he was killed because he was gay.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/merseyside/7868151.stm|publisher=BBC News|title=Teenager 'killed for being gay'|date=3 February 2009|accessdate=April 9, 2010}}</ref> * Daniel Jenkinson, 23, a gay [[hairdresser]], was the victim of a homophobic attack on 23 October 2008 in a [[Preston, Lancashire|Preston]] club. His attacker, Neil Bibby, also from Preston, was sentenced to 200 hours' unpaid work, a three-month weekend [[curfew]], and ordered to pay £2,000 [[Damages|compensation]] after he pleaded guilty to [[assault]]. Daniel needed facial reconstruction surgery after the attack, and said he was too scared to go out in the city.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lep.co.uk/news/Gay-man-suffers-homophobic-attack.4824255.jp|title=Gay man suffers homophobic attack in club|publisher=lep.co.uk|date=Dec 26, 2008|accessdate=2010-07-31}}</ref> * Gerry Edwards, 59, and his partner of over twenty years, Chris Bevan, 56, were stabbed by an assailant shouting homophobic abuse on 3 March 2009 in [[London Borough of Bromley|Bromley]], south London. Gerry died from his injuries, and Chris was admitted to hospital in a critical condition.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsshopper.co.uk/news/4175826.BICKLEY__Police_name_59_year_old_murder_victim/|title=BICKLEY: Police name 59-year-old murder victim|publisher=Newsshopper.co.uk|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=2010-07-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1159685/Man-stabbed-death-partner-seriously-wounded-homophobic-attack.html|title=Man stabbed to death and partner seriously wounded in 'homophobic attack'|publisher=[[The Daily Mail]]|date=6 March 2009|accessdate=2010-07-31|location=London}}</ref> The police dealing with the case said they had an open mind, but were treating it as a homophobic murder. Two men were subsequently arrested.<ref name="BROMLEY">{{Cite news|last=Taylor|first= Matthew|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2009/mar/06/fatal-stabbing-bromley-arrests|title= Two held over suspected homophobic murder|publisher=The Guardian|date=6 March 2009|location=London}}</ref> * [[Sol Campbell]], a [[association football|footballer]], was the target of disgruntled fans shouting homophobic abuse during a match. On 15 May 2009, an English court found two football fans guilty of shouting the homophobic chants.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/UK-News/Sol-Campbell-Two-Guilty-Of-Chanting-Gay-Boy-At-Portsmouth-Footballer-At-Match-Against-Tottenham/Article/200905315282355?lpos=UK_News_News_Your_Way_Region_6&lid=NewsYourWay_ARTICLE_15282355_Sol_Campbell%3A_Two_Guilty_Of_Chanting_Gay_Boy_At_Portsmouth_Footballer_At_Match_Against_Tottenham|title=Pair Guilty Of Sol Campbell 'Gay Boy' Chants |publisher=sky.com|accessdate=2009-05-15}}</ref> This was the first prosecution for indecent chanting in the UK.<ref name = SOL/> The police reported that up to 2,500 fans shouted chants at the match that included "Sol, Sol, wherever you may be, Not long now until lunacy, We won't give a fuck if you are hanging from a tree," the footballer commented "I felt totally victimised and helpless by the abuse I received on this day. It has had an effect on me personally".<ref name="SOL">{{Cite news|title=Pair guilty of homophobic chants at footballer Sol Campbell|publisher=The Guardian|date=15 May 2009|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2009/may/15/sol-campbell-chant-guilty-portsmouth|location=London}}</ref> Three men and two boys were given cautions after the match.<ref name="SOL" />
===Scotland=== In 2009, the [[Scottish parliament]] unanimously passed legislation that means that crimes motivated by hatred of gay or disabled people will now be considered as 'aggravated offences'.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/8078988.stm|title=MSPs approve new hate crime laws|publisher=BBC News|date=3 June 2009}}</ref>
*6 April 1960. Queen's Park (near Hampdem Park), Glasgow. John Cremin murder. John Cremin was hit over the head with a flat piece of wood by 19-year-old [[Anthony Miller (murderer)|Antony Miller]] after being lured from a public toilet by a 16-year-old accomplice James Denovan. Cremlin fell to the ground with a fractured skull and died due to massive haemorrhaging. He was robbed of his bankbook, wallet, a knife and £67. This led to the last hanging in Scotland at Barlinnie Prison, convicted murderer Antony Millar 19 years old, on 22 December 1960 - the last teenager to be hanged in the 20th century before the death penalty ended. Anthony Millar was buried within Barlinnie as was common with hanged prisoners. Accomplice James Denovan at 16 was too young in law to face the death penalty.<ref name="Otton">{{cite book|title=Sexual Fascism|first=Garry|last=Otton|isbn=0-9541131-0-1}}</ref> *Summer 1995. Michael Doran, 35 years old, was violently attacked and murdered in Queen's Park Glasgow by a gang of three lads and a girl went on a queer bashing rampage. He received 83 blows to his body and was stabbed several times in the groin and stamped on, and broke every bone in his face. The gang then joined a nearby party and bragged about what they had done.<ref name="Otton" /> *April 2007. James Kerr Murder. A teenager who murdered a gay council worker in a public park in Perth was jailed for life. David Meehan, 19, from Perth, admitted murdering James Kerr in a homophobic attack at South Inch Park in April. Mr Kerr, 51, was left lying in a pool of blood with major head injuries while Meehan and his accomplices went to a party. David Meehan will serve at least 16 years in jail.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/tayside_and_central/7090628.stm|title=Homophobic killer jailed for life|publisher=BBC News|date=12 November 2007|accessdate=2010-12-30}}</ref>
==United States== {{See also|History of violence against LGBT people in the United States}}
* Several men were assaulted on July 5, 1978, by a gang of youths armed with baseball bats and tree branches in an area of [[Central Park]] in New York City known to be frequented by homosexuals. The victims were assaulted at random, but the assailants later confessed that they had deliberately set out to the park to attack homosexuals. One of those injured was former figure skater [[Dick Button]], who was assaulted while watching a fireworks display in the park.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[The New York Times]]|date=July 7, 1978; July 8, 1978; July 9, 1978; July 13, 1978; July 14, 1978 |title=Dick Button}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.groups.yahoo.com/group/SkateFans/message/106545|title=Yahoo! Groups|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100219231652/http://sports.groups.yahoo.com/group/SkateFans/message/106545|archivedate=2010-02-19|df=}}</ref> * [[Harvey Milk]], the openly gay [[San Francisco]] city supervisor, along with Mayor [[George Moscone]], were assassinated on November 27, 1978, by political rival [[Dan White]] at San Francisco City Hall.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Double Play: The Hidden Passions Behind the Double Assassination of [[George Moscone]] and [[Harvey Milk]]|first=Mike|last=Weiss|year=2010|isbn=978-0-9825650-5-6|publisher=Vince Emery Productions}}</ref> Outrage over the assassinations and the short sentence given to White (seven years) prompted the [[White Night Riots]].<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Mayor of Castro Street: The Life and Times of Harvey Milk|first=Randy|last=Shilts|year=1988|isbn=0-312-01900-9|publisher=MacMillan}}</ref> * In March, 1979, an assault on several women in a [[Peg's Place (bar)|San Francisco lesbian bar]] by off-duty police officers drew national attention to the strained relationship between police and [[LGBT culture in San Francisco|LGBT San Franciscans]] at that time. One woman was hospitalized for ten days with skull injuries.<ref>Josh Sides, Erotic City: Sexual Revolutions and the Making of Modern San Francisco, Oxford University Press, Oct 19, 2009, p.165</ref> * [[Tennessee Williams]] was the victim of an assault in January 1979 in [[Key West]], being beaten by five teenage boys. He escaped serious injury. The episode was part of a spate of anti-gay violence inspired by an anti-gay newspaper ad run by a local [[Baptist]] minister.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/printout/0,8816,912357,00.html|title=Key West: The Last Resort|publisher=[[Time Magazine]]|date=February 19, 1979}}</ref> * Steven Charles, 17, of [[Newark, New Jersey|Newark]] was beaten to death in [[New York City]] on October 7, 1979, by [[Costabile Farace|Costabile "Gus" Farace]], Robert DeLicio, David Spoto and Farace's cousin Mark Granato. They also beat Charles' friend, 16-year-old Thomas Moore of Brooklyn. Moore was critically injured but managed to get help at a nearby residence. It was Moore that identified the four men via a lineup four days after the incident. Farace, the leader of the attack, plead guilty to first-degree manslaughter. He was paroled after 8 years, in 1988. He himself was murdered on November 17, 1989.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Raab|first=Selwyn|title=Five Families: The Rise, Decline, and Resurgence of America's Most Powerful Mafia Empires|volume=1|publisher=St. Martin's Press|publication-date=2005|isbn=0-312-30094-8|year=2005}}</ref> * On November 18, 1980, Ronald K. Crumpley, a former Transit Authority policeman, fired 40 rounds from a semiautomatic rifle and two Magnum pistols (all stolen from a Virginia gun shop) into a cluster of men standing in front of two gay bars—Ramroad and the next-door Sneakers—in West Greenwich Village, killing 21-year-old Jörg Wenz, from the Netherlands, the Ramrod's doorman, and 32-year-old Vernon Kroening, from Minnesota, a church organist, and wounding six others. Rene Malute, 23, later died of his wounds. A survivor described the shootings as "a massacre, a bloodbath." Crumpley admitted to having paranoid delusions that gays were agents of the devil, stalking him and "trying to steal my soul just by looking at me." He was found not responsible by reason of insanity and committed to maximum-security Kirby Forensic Psychiatric Center on Ward's Island. In 2001, a judge denied Crumpley's request to be transferred to a less restrictive psychiatric facility. * [[Charlie Howard (murder victim)|Charlie Howard]] was drowned in [[Bangor, Maine]], in 1984.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archive.seacoastonline.com/news/06202006/maine/108334.htm|title=Portsmouth Herald Maine News: Victim thrown from bridge formerly lived in Portsmouth|publisher=Archive.seacoastonline.com|date=June 20, 2006|accessdate=2010-07-31}}</ref> * [[Rebecca Wight]] was killed on May 13, 1988, when she and her partner, [[Claudia Brenner]], were shot by Stephen Roy Carr while hiking and camping along the [[Appalachian Trail]]. Carr later claimed that he became enraged by the couple's lesbianism when he saw them having sex.<ref>{{Cite book|last1=Brenna|first1= Claudia|last2=Ashley|first2= Hannah|title=Eight Bullets: One Woman's Story of Surviving Anti-Gay Violence|publisher=Firebrand Books|year=1995}}</ref> * [[James Zappalorti]] (1945–1990), a gay [[Vietnam War]] veteran, was stabbed to death.<ref name="nytimes">{{Cite news|publisher=[[The New York Times]]|title=S.I. Man, 44 Stabbed Dead On His Beach|first=James C.|last=McKinley, Jr.|date=January 25, 1990}}</ref> * [[Paul Broussard]] (1968–1991), a Houston-area banker, was murdered. * U.S. Navy Petty Officer [[Allen R. Schindler, Jr.|Allen Schindler]] was murdered by a shipmate who stomped him to death in a public restroom in Japan on October 27, 1992.<ref name="Jameson" /> Schindler had complained repeatedly about anti-gay harassment aboard ship.<ref name="Jameson">{{Cite news|last=Jameson|first=Sam|url=http://tech.mit.edu/V113/N28/sailor.28w.txt.html|accessdate=2008-03-21|title=U.S. Sailor Sentenced to Life Imprisonment in Murder|publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=28 May 1993}}</ref> The case became synonymous with the [[gays]] in the military debate that had been brewing in the United States culminating in the "[[Don't ask, don't tell]]" bill.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mylifetime.com/on-tv/movies/any-mothers-son |title=Any Mother's Son – About the Movie |publisher=[[Lifetime Television]] |accessdate=2008-01-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080126022232/http://www.mylifetime.com/on-tv/movies/any-mothers-son |archivedate=2008-01-26 |df= }}</ref> * [[Brandon Teena]], a [[transman]], was raped and later murdered in 1993 when his birth gender was revealed by police to male friends of his.<ref name="bbio">{{Cite book|last=Jones|first=Aphrodite|title=All She Wanted|publisher=Pocket Books|year=1996}}</ref> The events leading to Teena's death were depicted in the movie ''[[Boys Don't Cry (film)|Boys Don't Cry]]''.<ref name="bfilm">{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0171804/|title=Boys Don't Cry|publisher=[[IMDB]]}}</ref> * [[Scott Amedure]] was murdered on March 9, 1995, after revealing his attraction to his friend Jonathan Schmitz on a ''[[The Jenny Jones Show#The "Same Sex Crushes" controversy|The Jenny Jones Show]]'' episode about secret crushes. Schmitz purchased a shotgun to kill Amedure and did so after Amedure implied he still was attracted to him; Schmitz then turned himself in to police.<ref name="urlTalk-Show Guest Is Guilty Of Second-Degree Murder - New York Times">{{Cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D01E5DE113BF930A25752C1A960958260 |title=Talk-Show Guest Is Guilty Of Second-Degree Murder – New York Times |last=Bradsher |first=Keith |date=Nov 13, 1996 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5Z9xEOmO3?url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D01E5DE113BF930A25752C1A960958260 |archivedate=2008-07-08 |accessdate=2008-07-08 |publisher=The New York Times |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|last=Jennings|first=Marianne M.|title=Business: Its Legal, Ethical, and Global Environment|publisher=Thomson West|year=2005|page=388|isbn=0-324-20488-4}}</ref> * [[Roxanne Ellis and Michelle Abdill]], a [[lesbian]] couple in [[Medford, Oregon]], were murdered on December 4, 1995, by a man who said he had "no compassion" for bisexual or homosexual people.<ref>{{cite news|first=Charles|last=Burress|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/1996/08/22/MN50950.DTL|title=Confessed Stockton Slayer Tells Motive / He changes story, implies he killed 2 women because they were lesbians|publisher=Sfgate.com|date=Aug 22, 1996|accessdate=2010-07-31}}</ref> Robert Acremant was convicted and [[Capital punishment|sentenced to death]] by [[lethal injection]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archive.mailtribune.com/archive/2005/0318/local/stories/12local.htm|title=Death sentence upheld for lesbian couple's killer|publisher=Archive.mailtribune.com|date=March 18, 2005|accessdate=2010-07-31}}</ref> * On December 5, 1997, [[Ali Forney]] was found by the police shot on the sidewalk in front of a housing project on East 131st Street. According to the ''[[New York Times]]'' he was the third young [[transgender]] [[prostitute]] murdered in [[Harlem]] in 14 months. The killing has never been solved.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/12/opinion/editorial-observer-helping-them-make-it-through-the-night.html?scp=1&sq=editorial%20Ali%20Forney&st=cse|title=Editorial Observer; Helping Them Make It Through the Night|publisher=The New York Times|date=July 12, 1998|accessdate=2016-07-09}}</ref> * The Otherside Lounge, a lesbian nightclub in [[Atlanta]], was bombed by [[Eric Robert Rudolph]], the "[[Centennial Olympic Park bombing|Olympic Park Bomber]]," on February 21, 1997; five bar patrons were injured. In a statement released after he was sentenced to five consecutive life terms for his several bombings, Rudolph called homosexuality an "aberrant lifestyle". * [[Matthew Shepard]] (1976–1998), a gay student, was fatally attacked in [[Laramie, Wyoming]] on October 7, 1998. Shepard was tortured, beaten severely, tied to a fence, and abandoned; he was found 18 hours after the attack and succumbed to his injuries less than a week later, on October 12. His attackers, Russell Arthur Henderson and Aaron James McKinney, are both serving two consecutive life sentences in prison.<ref>{{cite news|first=Michael|last=Janofsky|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/11/05/us/parents-of-gay-obtain-mercy-for-his-killer.html|title=Parents of Gay Obtain Mercy For His Killer|publisher=The New York Times|date=November 5, 1999|accessdate=April 9, 2010}}</ref> * [[Gary Matson]] and [[Winfield Mowder]], a gay couple, were murdered on July 1, 1999, by [[white supremacist]] brothers Matthew and Tyler Williams in [[Redding, California]]. Tyler Williams was sentenced to a minimum of 33 years in prison, to be served after his completion of a 21-year sentence for firebombing synagogues and an abortion clinic.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/niot/citizens_respond/redding.html|title=Not In Our Town - Citizens Respond to Hate - Redding|publisher=[[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]]|accessdate=2010-07-31}}</ref> Benjamin Williams claimed that by killing the couple he was "obeying the laws of the Creator".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gaypeopleschronicle.com/stories/99nov12.htm|title=Lead News Stories from the Gay People's Chronicle|publisher=[[Gay People's Chronicle]]|accessdate=2010-07-31}}</ref> He committed suicide in 2003 while awaiting trial. Their former pastor described the brothers as "zealous in their faith" but "far from kooks".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.salon.com/news/feature/1999/10/06/redding/print.html |title=Poster boys for the summer of hate |publisher=[[Salon.com|Salon]] |date=Oct 6, 1999 |accessdate=2010-07-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110926093339/http://www.salon.com/news/feature/1999/10/06/redding/print.html |archivedate=2011-09-26 |df= }}</ref> * U.S. Army Pfc. [[Barry Winchell]] was murdered on July 6, 1999, in [[Fort Campbell]], Kentucky by fellow soldier Calvin Glover. Winchell was beaten to death with a baseball bat after rumors spread on base of his relationship with transgender author [[Calpernia Addams]]. Glover was sentenced to life in prison.<ref>{{cite web|url=//www.davidclemens.com/gaymilitary/rolstobarry.htm |title=The Execution of Private Winchell |publisher=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=March 2, 2000 |accessdate=2010-07-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060213230320/http://www.davidclemens.com/gaymilitary/rolstobarry.htm |archivedate=February 13, 2006 |df= }}</ref> * [[Steen Fenrich]] was murdered in September 1999, apparently by his stepfather, John D. Fenrich, in [[Queens]], New York. His dismembered remains were found in March 2001, with the phrase "gay nigger number one" scrawled on his skull along with his social security number. His stepfather fled from police while being interviewed, then committed suicide.<ref>{{cite news|first=David M.|last=Herszenhorn|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/03/24/nyregion/signs-in-grisly-killing-point-to-bias-and-stepfather-who-killed-himself.html?sec=health&spon=&pagewanted=all|title=Signs in Grisly Killing Point to Bias and Stepfather Who Killed Himself|publisher=The New York Times|date=March 24, 2000|accessdate=April 9, 2010}}</ref> * [[Arthur Warren|Arthur "J.R." Warren]] was punched and kicked to death by two teenage boys on July 3, 2000, in [[Grant Town, West Virginia]], who reportedly believed Warren had spread a rumor that he and one of the boys, David Allen Parker, had a sexual relationship. Warren's killers ran over his body to disguise the murder as a [[Hit and run (vehicular)|hit-and-run]]. Parker pleaded guilty and was sentenced to "life in prison with mercy", making him eligible for parole after 15 years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/print?id=92841|title=Teen Pleads Guilty in Gay Slay|publisher=[[ABC News]]|date=July 4, 2000|accessdate=2010-07-31}}</ref> His accomplice, Jared Wilson, was sentenced to 20 years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gaypeopleschronicle.com/stories/01aug24.htm|title=Lead News Stories from the Gay People's Chronicle|publisher=Gay People's Chronicle|date=Aug 14, 2000|accessdate=2010-07-31}}</ref> * [[Ronald Gay]] entered a gay bar in [[Roanoke, Virginia]] on September 22, 2000, and opened fire on the patrons, killing Danny Overstreet, 43 years old, and severely injuring six others. Ronald said he was angry over what his name now meant, and deeply upset that three of his sons had changed their surname. He claimed that he had been told by [[God]] to find and kill lesbians and gay men, describing himself as a "Christian Soldier working for my Lord;" Gay testified in court that "he wished he could have killed more fags," before several of the shooting victims as well as Danny Overstreet's family and friends.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/942255.stm|title=Murder charge for gay-bar gunman|publisher=BBC News|date=September 25, 2000|accessdate=April 9, 2010}}</ref> * [[Nizah Morris]], a [[trans woman]], was the victim of a possible homicide in December 2002 in [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]]. * [[Gwen Araujo]], a [[trans woman]], was murdered by at least three men who were charged with committing a hate crime. Two were convicted of murder, the third manslaughter; however, the jury rejected the hate crime enhancement. * [[Sakia Gunn]], a 15-year-old lesbian, was murdered on May 11, 2003, in [[Newark, New Jersey]]. While waiting for a bus, Gunn and her friends were propositioned by two men. When the girls rejected their advances, declaring themselves to be lesbians, the men attacked them. One of the men, Richard McCullough, fatally stabbed Gunn. In exchange for his pleading guilty to several lesser crimes including aggravated manslaughter, prosecutors dropped murder charges against McCullough, who was sentenced to 20 years.<ref>{{cite news|first=Ronald|last=Smothers|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/05/12/nyregion/newark-preaches-tolerance-of-gays-year-after-killing.html|title=Newark Preaches Tolerance Of Gays Year After Killing|publisher=The New York Times|date=May 12, 2004|accessdate=April 9, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|last=Castañeda|first=Laura|author2=Shannon B. Campbell |title=News and Sexuality: Media Portraits of Diversity|year=2004|publisher=SAGE|isbn=0-7619-2814-6 |quote=9780761928140 |pages=161–165, 293}}</ref> * [[Guin Richie Phillips|Richie Phillips]] of [[Elizabethtown, Kentucky]] was killed on June 17, 2003, by Joseph Cottrell. His body was later found in a suitcase in [[Rough River Lake]]. During his trial, two of Cottrell's relatives testified that he lured Phillips to his death, and killed him because he was gay.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.enquirer.com/editions/2003/08/27/loc_kysuitcasebody27.html|title=Family of murder suspect speak out|publisher=[[National Enquirer]]|accessdate=2010-07-31}}</ref> Cottrell was convicted of manslaughter and sentenced to 20 years in prison.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Cottrell, appeal |publisher=[[Kentucky Supreme Court]] |url=http://162.114.92.72/Opinions/2005-SC-000181-MR.pdf |accessdate=2009-05-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110703120119/http://162.114.92.72/Opinions/2005-SC-000181-MR.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-03 |df= }}</ref> * [[Nireah Johnson]] and Brandie Coleman were shot to death on July 23, 2003, by Paul Moore when Moore learned after a sexual encounter that Johnson was [[transgender]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gaywired.com/print_this_article.cfm?section=9&id=2678|title=gay.com Daily|publisher=Gaywired.com|accessdate=2010-07-31}}</ref> Moore then burned his victims' bodies. He was convicted of murder and sentenced to 120 years in prison.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.in.gov/judiciary/opinions/archive/05230502.tac.html|title=Converted file tac|publisher=In.gov|accessdate=2010-07-31}}</ref> * [[Murder of Glenn Kopitske|Glenn Kopitske]], 37, was shot and stabbed in the back on July 31, 2003, by 17-year-old Gary Hirte, a straight-A student, star athlete and [[Eagle Scout (Boy Scouts of America)|Eagle Scout]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www3.jsonline.com/story/index.aspx?id=19381 |title=Weyauwega Scout, 16, reaches lofty goal |publisher=JS Online |date=Feb 11, 2002 |accessdate=2010-07-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929134227/http://www.jsonline.com/story/index.aspx?id=19381 |archivedate=2007-09-29 |df= }}</ref> in [[Winnebago County, Wisconsin]]. Prosecutors contended that Hirte murdered Kopitske to see if he could get away with it.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wisn.com/news/4146869/detail.html |title=Defense Attorney Drops Bombshell In Honor Student's Murder Trial |publisher=WISN Milwaukee |date=January 31, 2005 |accessdate=2010-07-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928063550/http://www.wisn.com/news/4146869/detail.html |archivedate=September 28, 2007 |df= }}</ref> Hirte pleaded insanity, claiming he killed Kopitske in a murderous rage after a consensual sexual encounter with the victim, because he felt a homosexual act was "worse than murder". The 'temporary insanity' mitigation plea was not upheld, he was found guilty, and received a [[Life imprisonment|life sentence]]. * [[Scotty Joe Weaver]] was an 18-year-old murder victim from [[Bay Minette, Alabama]], whose burned and partially decomposed body was discovered on July 22, 2004, a few miles from the mobile home in which he lived. He was beaten, strangled and stabbed numerous times, partially decapitated, and his body was doused in gasoline and set on fire. * [[Ronnie Paris|Ronnie Antonio Paris]], a three-year-old boy living in [[Tampa, Florida]], died on January 28, 2005, due to brain injuries inflicted by his father, Ronnie Paris, Jr. According to his mother and other relatives, Ronnie Paris, Jr., repeatedly slammed his son into walls, slapped the child's head, and "[[Boxing|boxed]]" him because he was concerned the child was gay and would grow up a sissy. Paris was sentenced to thirty years in prison.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.advocate.com/news_detail_ektid18908.asp |title=Florida man convicted of murdering 3-year-old "gay" son |publisher=Advocate |accessdate=2010-07-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090202183335/http://www.advocate.com/news_detail_ektid18908.asp |archivedate=2009-02-02 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sptimes.com/2005/08/20/Hillsborough/Dad_sentenced_to_30_y.shtml|title=Dad sentenced to 30 years in death of boy, 3|publisher=Sptimes.com|date=Aug 20, 2005|accessdate=2010-07-31}}</ref> * [[Jason Gage]], an openly gay man, was murdered on March 11, 2005, in his [[Waterloo, Iowa]] apartment by an assailant, Joseph Lawrence, who claimed [[Jason Gage|Gage]] had made sexual advance to him. Gage was [[Club (weapon)|bludgeoned]] to death with a bottle, and stabbed in the neck, probably post-mortem, with a shard of glass.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wcfcourier.com/articles/2005/03/31/news/metro/dc7e7d835fa746af86256fd5004ca40a.txt|title=Fine print hints at hate crime|publisher=Wcfcourier.com|date=March 31, 2005|accessdate=2010-07-31}}</ref> Lawrence was sentenced to fifty years in prison. * 18-year-old [[Jacob D. Robida]] entered a bar on February 2, 2006, in [[New Bedford, Massachusetts]], confirmed that it was a [[gay bar]], and then attacked patrons with a hatchet and a handgun, wounding three.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2006/US/02/02/gay.shooting/index.html|publisher=CNN|title=Man, 18, sought after gun, hatchet attack at gay bar| accessdate=April 9, 2010}}</ref> He fatally shot himself three days later.<ref>{{cite news|first=John R.|last=Ellement|url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2006/02/07/autopsy_robida_shot_himself|title=Autopsy: Robida shot himself|publisher=[[The Boston Globe]]|date=Feb 7, 2006|accessdate=2010-07-31}}</ref> * [[Kevin Aviance]], a female impressionist, musician, and fashion designer, was robbed and beaten in [[Manhattan]] on June 10, 2006, by a group of men who yelled anti-gay slurs at him. Four assailants pleaded guilty and received prison sentences.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/people/2006-06-11-singer-hate-crime_x.htm|title=Singer Aviance leaves N.Y. hospital after beating|publisher=[[USA Today]]|date=June 12, 2006|accessdate=April 9, 2010}}</ref> * Six men were attacked with [[baseball bat]]s and knives on July 30, 2006, after leaving the [[San Diego, California]] [[Gay Pride]] festival. One victim was injured so severely that he had to undergo extensive facial reconstructive surgery. Three men pleaded guilty in connection with the attacks and received prison sentences. A 15-year-old juvenile also pleaded guilty.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfbaytimes.com/index.php?article_id=5335&sec=article|title=San Francisco Bay Times|publisher=Sfbaytimes.com|date=Aug 3, 2006|accessdate=2010-07-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sgn.org/sgnnews34_39/page4.cfm|title=SGN Page 4|publisher=Sgn.org|date=Sep 29, 2006|accessdate=2010-07-31}}</ref> * An [[2006 Greenwich Village assault case|altercation]] occurred in Manhattan on August 18, 2006, between a man and seven black lesbians from Newark, New Jersey. During the altercation, the man was stabbed. The women claim that they acted in self-defense after he screamed homophobic epithets, spit on them, and pulled one of their weaves off,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/04/14/nyregion/14assault.html?ex=1177128000&en=a1ea123367fd1a57&ei=5099&partner=TOPIXNEWS|title=Woman in Gang Assault Trial Says Man Started the Fight|last=Hartocollis|first=Anemona|date=Apr 14, 2007|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=2009-03-17}}</ref> while he has described the attack as "a hate crime against a straight man."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/19233888/|title=Four women sentenced over attack on man|date=June 15, 2007|publisher=MSNBC|accessdate=2009-01-14}}</ref> * [[Michael Sandy]] was attacked on October 8, 2006, by four young [[heterosexual]] men who lured him into meeting after chatting online, while they were looking for gay men to rob. He was struck by a car while trying to escape his attackers, and died five days later without regaining consciousness.<ref name="NYT1121">{{Cite journal|first=Michael|last=Brick|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/11/21/nyregion/21plumb.html|title=Three Sentenced in Death of Gay Man|date=Nov 21, 2007|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=2007-11-21}}</ref><ref name="DAILYNEWS1121">{{Cite journal|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/ny_crime/2007/11/21/2007-11-21_three_who_killed_michael_sandy_get_nearm-2.html|first=Scott|last=Shifrel|title=Three who killed Michael Sandy get near-maximum sentence for hate crime|date=Nov 21, 2007|publisher=[[The New York Daily News]]|accessdate=2007-11-21}}</ref> * Andrew Anthos, a 72-year-old disabled gay man, was beaten with a lead pipe by a man who was shouting anti-gay names at him on February 27, 2007, in [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]]. Anthos died 10 days later in the hospital.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.advocate.com/news_detail_ektid42467.asp|title=Sketch released of suspect in Detroit gay bashing|publisher=Advocate|accessdate=2010-07-31}}</ref> * Sean William Kennedy, 20, was walking to his car from Brew's Bar in [[Greenville, SC]] on May 16, 2007, when Stephen Andrew Moller, 18, got out of another car and approached Kennedy. Investigators said that Moller made a comment about Kennedy's sexual orientation, and threw a fatal punch because he did not like the other man's sexual preference.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.wyff4.com/news/13345546/detail.html|title=Deputies: Man Punched, Killed Because He Was Gay|publisher=WYFF Greenville|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101208085307/http://www.wyff4.com/news/13345546/detail.html|archivedate=2010-12-08|df=}}</ref> * Duanna Johnson, a transsexual woman, was beaten by a police officer in February 2008, while she was held in the Shelby County Criminal Justice Center in Tennessee. Johnson said the officers reportedly called her a "faggot" and "he-she," before and during the incident.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kctv5.com/news/16654585/detail.html |title=Transsexual Beaten; Officer Fired |publisher=KCTV Kansas City |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080801091622/http://www.kctv5.com/news/16654585/detail.html |archivedate=2008-08-01 |df= }}</ref> In November 2008, she was found dead in the street, reportedly gunned down by three unknown individuals.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.myeyewitnessnews.com/news/local/story.aspx?content_id=f3bb7d09-2602-4c9f-a033-2b9f8fca3018|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120906115240/http://www.myeyewitnessnews.com/news/local/story.aspx?content_id=f3bb7d09-2602-4c9f-a033-2b9f8fca3018|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2012-09-06|title=Homicide Victim Identified as Transgendered Person, Duanna Johnson}}</ref> * [[Lawrence "Larry" King]], a 15-year-old junior highschool student was shot twice by a classmate at E.O. Green School in [[Oxnard, California]] on February 12, 2008. He was taken off life support after doctors declared him [[Brain death|brain dead]] on February 15.<ref name="Newsweek">{{Cite news|last=Setoodeh|first=Ramin|title=Young, Gay and Murdered|url=http://www.newsweek.com/id/147790&GT1=43002|publisher=[[Newsweek]]|date=July 19, 2008|accessdate=2008-07-23}}</ref> According to [[Associated Press]] reports, ''"prosecutors have charged a 14-year-old classmate with premeditated murder with hate-crime and firearm-use enhancements"''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ebar.com/news/article.php?sec=news&article=2715|title=Breaking news: Vigil Tues. for slain Oxnard teen|publisher=[[The Bay Area Reporter]] Online}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ksby.com/Global/story.asp?S=7881176 |title=Organs harvested from Oxnard school shooting victim |publisher=KSBY 6 Action News |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080609225931/http://www.ksby.com/Global/story.asp?S=7881176 |archivedate=2008-06-09 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.venturacountystar.com/news/2008/feb/15/no-headline---na1fcvictimfamily15/ |title=Victim's family members say they will donate teen's organs |publisher=[[Ventura County Star]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080908060643/http://www.venturacountystar.com/news/2008/feb/15/no-headline---na1fcvictimfamily15/ |archivedate=2008-09-08 |df= }}</ref> * [[Angie Zapata]], an 18-year-old trans woman, was beaten to death on July 17, 2008, in [[Colorado]], two days after meeting Allen Ray Andrade. The case was prosecuted as a hate crime, and Andrade was found guilty of first degree murder on April 22, 2009.<ref>{{cite web|last=Dunn |first=Sharon |url=http://www.greeleytribune.com/article/20090423/NEWS/904229934/1002/NONE&parentprofile=1001 |title=Andrade guilty, sentenced to life in murder of Angie Zapata |publisher=Greeley Tribune |date=April 23, 2009 |accessdate=2010-07-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090426134201/http://www.greeleytribune.com/article/20090423/NEWS/904229934/1002/NONE%26parentprofile%3D1001 |archivedate=April 26, 2009 |df= }}</ref> * Nima Daivari, 26, was attacked by a man who called him "faggot" on September 13, 2008, in [[Denver, Colorado]]. The police that arrived on the scene refused to make a report of the attack.<ref>{{cite news|first=Susan|last=Greene|url=http://www.denverpost.com/news/ci_10459273|title=Gay attack swept under the shrug|publisher=[[The Denver Post]]|accessdate=2010-07-31|date=September 14, 2008}}</ref> * A [[Bourbonnais, Illinois]] [[elementary school]] [[bus driver]] was charged with leading a homophobic attack on a 10-year-old student passenger on September 15, 2008. The boy was taunted by the driver who then encouraged other students to chase and [[assault|beat]] the child.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.daily-journal.com/news/local/bourbonnais-bus-driver-arrested-after-alleged-taunting/article_29d34a3f-6647-57aa-8944-5ceea9b32e94.html/|title=SBourbonnais bus driver arrested after alleged taunting|publisher=daily-journal.com|date=Oct 10, 2008|accessdate=2016-10-18}}</ref> * Lateisha Green, a 22-year-old transgender woman, was shot and killed by Dwight DeLee on November 14, 2008, in [[Syracuse, New York|Syracuse]], [[New York (state)|NY]] because he thought she was gay.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.californiachronicle.com/articles/82102 |title=Lateisha Green's Death Highlights Need for Comprehensive Hate Crimes Legislation |publisher=[[California Chronicle]] |accessdate=2010-07-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110911144825/http://www.californiachronicle.com/articles/82102 |archivedate=2011-09-11 |df= }}</ref> Local news media reported the incident with her legal name, Moses "Teish" Cannon.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.syracuse.com/news/index.ssf/2008/11/syracuse_man_was_killed_for_be.html|title=Syracuse man was killed for being gay, police say|publisher=syracuse.com|date=Nov 16, 2008|accessdate=2010-07-31}}</ref> DeLee was convicted of first-degree manslaughter as a hate crime on July 17, 2009, and received the maximum sentence of 25 years in state prison. This was only the second time in the nation's history that a person was prosecuted for a hate crime against a transgender person and the first hate crime conviction in New York state.<ref>{{cite web|last=Garcia|first=Michelle|url=http://www.advocate.com/news_detail_ektid99146.asp|title=DeLee Found Guilty in Trans Killing|publisher=Advocate|accessdate=2010-07-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Bolcer |first=Julie |url=http://www.advocate.com/News/Daily_News/2009/08/18/Lateisha_Green_Murderer_Sentenced |title=Lateisha Green Murderer Sentenced |publisher=Advocate |accessdate=2010-07-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090927000852/http://www.advocate.com/News/Daily_News/2009/08/18/Lateisha_Green_Murderer_Sentenced/ |archivedate=2009-09-27 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|first=Dick|last=Blume|url=http://www.syracuse.com/news/index.ssf/2009/08/dwight_delee_to_be_sentenced_i.html|title=Dwight DeLee gets the maximum in transgender slaying|publisher=syracuse.com|accessdate=2010-07-31}}</ref> * Carl Joseph Walker-Hoover, an 11-year-old child in [[Springfield, Massachusetts]], hanged himself with an extension cord on April 6, 2009, after being bullied all school year by peers who said "he acted feminine" and was gay.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thebostonchannel.com/cnn-news/19141470/detail.html|title=Mother Says Bullies Drove Her Son To Suicide|publisher=[[Boston News]]|date=April 9, 2009|accessdate=2010-07-31|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100109080802/http://www.thebostonchannel.com/cnn-news/19141470/detail.html|archivedate=January 9, 2010|df=}}</ref> * Justin Goodwin, 36, of [[Salem, Massachusetts]] was attacked and beaten on April 10, 2009, by as many as six people outside a bar in [[Gloucester, Massachusetts]]. Goodwin suffered a shattered jaw, broken eye socket, broken nose and broken cheekbone. Goodwin later committed suicide.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.salemnews.com/news/local_news/trial-starting-in-beating-of-gay-man/article_630fe4e3-da44-530a-ab63-a831fe1e09f0.html|title=Trial starting in beating of gay man|publisher=salemnews.com|date=Apr 4, 2012|accessdate=2016-10-18}}</ref> * [[Seaman]] [[August Provost]] was found shot to death and his body burned at his guard post on [[Camp Pendleton]] on June 30, 2009. LGBT community leaders "citing military sources initially said that Provost's death was a hate crime."<ref name="GLTP">{{cite news|first=Rick |last=Braatz |url=http://www.gaylesbiantimes.com/?id=15098 |title=GLBT community honors life of murdered seaman: Veterans use tragic death as rallying cry against ‘DADT’ |publisher=[[Gay and Lesbian Times]] |date=16 July 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110926122515/http://www.gaylesbiantimes.com/?id=15098 |archivedate=26 September 2011 |df= }}</ref> Provost had been harassed because of his sexual orientation.<ref name="GLTP" /> Military leaders have since explained that "whatever the investigation concludes, the military's "[[Don't ask, don't tell]]" policy prevented Provost from seeking help."<ref name="GLTP" /> Family and friends believe he was murdered because he was openly gay (or bisexual according to some family and sources);<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/CRIME/07/03/california.sailor.death/|title=Sailor gunned down on sentry duty, Navy says|publisher=CNN|date=July 3, 2009|accessdate=April 9, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/pam-spaulding/new-twist-in-bisexual-sai_b_237906.html?&just_reloaded=1|title=Pam Spaulding: New Twist in Bisexual Sailor's Murder - Victim's Aunt Says Suspect Feared Being Outed|publisher=The Huffington Post|accessdate=2010-07-31|date=July 17, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtonmonthly.com/archives/individual/2009_07/018937.php|title=The Washington Monthly|publisher=[[The Washington Monthly]]|date=Jul 5, 2009|accessdate=2010-07-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxturtlebulletin.com/tag/august-provost|title=August Provost|publisher=[[Box Turtle Bulletin]]|accessdate=2010-07-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://glaadblog.org/2009/07/09/remembering-an-openly-gay-%E2%80%9Crising-star-in-our-navy%E2%80%9D// |title=Remembering an Openly Gay "Rising Star in Our Navy" |publisher=GLAADBlog.org |accessdate=2010-07-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100616110516/http://glaadblog.org/2009/07/09/remembering-an-openly-gay-%E2%80%9Crising-star-in-our-navy%E2%80%9D/ |archivedate=2010-06-16 |df= }}</ref> the killer committed suicide a week later after admitting the murder. The Navy has not concluded if this was a hate crime.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sandiego6.com/news/local/story/Suspect-in-Camp-Pendleton-murder-suicide-Campos/IQBbCHMiw02AFACT2PkbeA.cspx |title=Suspect in Gay Sailor's Murder Found Dead |publisher=San Diego 6 |accessdate=2010-07-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090805090858/http://www.sandiego6.com/news/local/story/Suspect-in-Camp-Pendleton-murder-suicide-Campos/IQBbCHMiw02AFACT2PkbeA.cspx |archivedate=2009-08-05 |df= }}</ref> * [[CeCe McDonald]], a young African American trans woman, was attacked outside a tavern shortly after midnight on June 5, 2011, in Minneapolis, Minnesota.<ref>{{cite web|last=Mannix |first=Andy |title=CeCe McDonald murder trial |url=http://www.citypages.com/2012-05-09/news/cece-mcdonald-murder-trial/ |publisher=Minneapolis City Pages |accessdate=2014-01-14 |date=2012-05-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140122144811/http://www.citypages.com/2012-05-09/news/cece-mcdonald-murder-trial/ |archivedate=2014-01-22 |df= }}</ref> CeCe fatally stabbed her attacker with a pair of scissors.<ref>{{cite news|last=Pearce|first=Matt|title=Transgender woman sentenced to men's prison in Minnesota killing|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2012/jun/18/nation/la-na-nn-transgender-woman-sentenced-to-mens-prison-20120618|publisher=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=2014-01-14|date=2012-06-18}}</ref> She was subsequently convicted of [[manslaughter]] and jailed for 19 months in a men's prison.<ref>{{cite web|last=Merevick|first=Tony|title=After 19 Months In Men's Prison, CeCe McDonald Released|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/tonymerevick/after-19-months-in-mens-prison-cece-mcdonald-released|publisher=BuzzFeed|accessdate=2014-01-14|date=2014-01-13}}</ref> * Mark Carson, a 32-year-old gay man, was shot to death by a man who trailed and taunted him and a friend as they walked down the street in [[Greenwich Village]], [[New York (state)|New York]], yelling anti-gay slurs and asking one of them, "You want to die tonight?" Elliot Morales was arrested briefly after the shooting and charged with murder and weapons charges on May 19, 2013.<ref>{{cite news|last=Barron|first=James|title=Charges Filed in Killing of Gay Man in Greenwich Village|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/20/nyregion/greenwich-village-alleged-antigay-killing.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|accessdate=May 20, 2013|newspaper=''[[The New York Times]]''|date=May 19, 2013}}</ref> * 49 people were killed, and 53 injured, in a [[2016 Orlando nightclub shooting|shooting at an Orlando gay nightclub]] on June 12, 2016.

{{DISPLAYTITLE:static_cast}} In [[C++]] [[type conversion]], the '''static_cast''' [[Operators in C and C++|operator]] performs an explicit type conversion.<ref>{{cite book|title=Programming: Principles and Practice Using C++|year=2008|publisher=Addison-Wesley|location=United States of America|isbn=0321543726|pages=594}}</ref>
==Syntax== <source lang=cpp> static_cast<type> (object); </source>
The ''type'' parameter must be a data type to which ''object'' can be converted via a known method, whether it be a builtin or a cast. The type can be a reference or an enumerator. All types of conversions that are well-defined and allowed by the compiler are performed using static_cast.<ref>{{cite book|title=Thinking in C++|year=2000|publisher=Alan Apt|location=United States of America|isbn=0-13-979809-9|pages=857}}</ref>
The static_cast operator can be used for operations such as: * Converting a pointer of a base class to a pointer of a nonvirtual derived class, * Converting numeric data types such as [[Enumerated type|enums]] to [[Integer (computer science)|ints]] or ints to [[Floating point|floats]].
Although static_cast conversions are checked at compile time to prevent obvious incompatibilities, no [[Type system#Dynamic typing|run-time type check]] is performed that would prevent a cast between incompatible data types, such as pointers. Also, the result of a static_cast from a pointer of a virtual base class to a pointer of a derived class is undefined.
==See also== * [[dynamic cast]] * [[reinterpret_cast]] * [[const_cast]] * [[duration_cast]]

[[File:Stefan Gandler 2018 in Mexico City.jpg|thumb|upright=1.5|Stefan Gandler (2018)]] '''Stefan Gandler''' (born 1964 in [[Munich]]) is a [[philosopher]] and [[Social science|social scientist]]. He studied at [[Goethe University of Frankfurt|Frankfurt University]] and has lived in [[Mexico]] since 1993<ref>[http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no00018261.html Library of Congress Name Authority File].</ref><ref>[http://www.brill.com/products/book/critical-marxism-mexico Koninklijke Brill NV: ''Biographical note'']</ref>
== Life == Gandler studied [[Philosophy]], [[Latin American studies]], [[Romance studies|Romance Languages and Literatures]] and [[Political science]] in Frankfurt/Main, among others with [[Alfred Schmidt (philosopher)|Alfred Schmidt]], and he was the Chairman of the Frankfurt [[AStA|General Students' Committee (AStA)]] in 1989/90.<ref>[http://de.scribd.com/doc/239505483/Winkel ''Abschied vom Intellektuellen''] (Detlef zum Winkel in ''konkret'', 2/1990, S. 59–61.)</ref>
1997 Stefan Gandler earned his doctorate with a study on ''Contemporary [[Social philosophy]] in [[Mexico]]'',<ref>Arturo Jiménez: [http://www.jornada.unam.mx/2007/09/28/index.php?section=cultura&article=a06n1cul ''Stefan Gandler publica en español libro que amplía su tesis doctoral contra el eurocentrismo. Reivindica estudioso el marxismo crítico de Sánchez Vázquez y Bolívar Echeverría.''] In: ''La Jornada.'' México, September 28, 2007, p. 6a.</ref> which has been translated in two languages.<ref>Stefan Gandler: ''Marxismo crítico en México. Adolfo Sánchez Vázquez y Bolívar Echeverría.'' Fondo de Cultura Económica, México 2007, {{ISBN|978-968-16-8404-4}}; Stefan Gandler: ''Critical Marxism in Mexico. Adolfo Sánchez Vázquez and Bolívar Echeverría.'' (Historical Materialism Book Series). Brill Academic Press, Leiden 2015.</ref> 1997 Gandler was tenured as professor for Social theory and Social Philosophy at the [[Autonomous University of Queretaro|Universidad Autónoma de Querétaro (UAQ)]] and has this position until today, and since 2008 he is additionally permanent invited professor for philosophy at the [[National Autonomous University of Mexico|Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México]].<ref>Gandler is PhD adviser in the UNAM doctorate program in philosophy in three areas: [http://www.posgrado.unam.mx/filosofia/docs/tut_politica.html Political philosophy], [http://www.posgrado.unam.mx/filosofia/docs/tut_cultura.html Philosophy of culture] and [http://www.posgrado.unam.mx/filosofia/docs/tut_estetica.html Aesthetics].</ref> Gandler is also, since 2001, member of the [[Sistema Nacional de Investigadores]]<ref>[http://www.conacyt.gob.mx/index.php/el-conacyt/sistema-nacional-de-investigadores Sistema Nacional de Investigadores homepage]</ref> (category 3)<ref>[http://www.conacyt.gob.mx/images/SNI/BENEFICIARIOS_2017.xlsx Sistema Nacional de Investigadores: Padrón de Benificiarios], [http://www.conacyt.gob.mx/images/SNI/2016/Ingreso_o_Permanencia_SNI_2016.pdf Sistema Nacional de Investigadores: Resultados de la Convocatoria 2016, Ingreso o Permanencia]</ref> and founded in 2012 the Research Project on Critical Theory from the Americas<ref>[http://www.conacyt.gob.mx/FondosyApoyos/Sectoriales/InvestigacionBasicaAplicada/SEP/Basica/Documents/Resultados_Convocatoria_CB-2011_publicacion.pdf CONACYT, ''Resultados de la convocatoria'']</ref> of the [[Consejo Nacional de Ciencia y Tecnología (Mexico)|National Council of Science and Technology (CONACYT)]]. Gandler is since 2007 chair of the academic group ''Modernity, development and region''<ref>[http://promep.sep.gob.mx/CA1/ Cuerpo Académico Modernidad, Desarrollo y Región]</ref> from the [[Secretariat of Public Education (Mexico)|Mexican Federal Education Authority]].<ref>Gandler/Serna/Palacios (eds.), [http://biblioteca.diputados.gob.mx/janium/bv/ce/scpd/LXI/mode_difer.pdf ''Modernidad y diferencia. Reflexiones conceptuales y estudios empíricos en género y territorio''.] México, D.F./Querétaro, Miguel Ángel Porrúa /Universidad Autónoma de Querétaro/H. Cámara de Diputados, 2010, p. 123 and [http://fcps.uaq.mx/plantilladocente/dr_stefan_josef_gandler/ UAQ homepage] This academic group has published five collective books.</ref> (SEP)<ref>Secretaría de Educación Pública, [http://dsa.sep.gob.mx/prodep.html PRODE] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160119170301/http://dsa.sep.gob.mx/prodep.html |date=2016-01-19 }}.</ref> In his sabbatical years he researched und taught<ref>[http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:NULLCVymEQQJ:www.conacyt.mx/index.php/el-conacyt/convocatorias-y-resultados-conacyt/convocatorias-estancias-sabaticas/sabaticas-2015/9118-publicacion-resultados-2015/file+&cd=4&hl=de&ct=clnk&gl=us with the approval of the CONACYT: ''Resultados de la convocatoria'']</ref> at the [[Goethe University of Frankfurt|Universität Frankfurt am Main]] (2001/2002), the [[University of California, Santa Cruz]] (2009/2010)<ref>[http://www.gew-hessen.de/fileadmin/user_upload/veroeffentlichungen/hlz/1001-02_hlz.pdf "... the Californian University professor Stefan Gandler" (Matthias Freiling, ''Eine Woche Bildungsstreik in Frankfurt.'' In: ''HLZ. Zeitschrift der GEW Hessen'', Frankfurt/Main, year 63, no.1/2, jan.-feb. 2010, pp. 10-11.]</ref><ref>[http://ccs.ihr.ucsc.edu/wp-content/uploads/2010/07/Winter2010.pdf Center for Cultural Studies, UCSC: announcement]</ref> and the [[Tulane University]], New Orleans (2015/2016).<ref>[http://stonecenter.tulane.edu/articles/detail/2027/For-a-Critical-Theory-from-the-Americas-A-talk-by-Prof.-Stefan-Gandler Roger Thayer Stone Center For Latin American Studies, Tulane University: announcement]</ref>
The main research fields of Stefan Gandler are the [[Critical theory]] of the [[Frankfurt School]], the critical [[Western Marxism|''western'' Marxism]], philosophy in Latin America, [[Critique of ideology]] and [[Walter Benjamin]].<ref>"With sixteen books and over 150 articles published on critical theory, German philosophy, and Marxism in the Americas, Stefan Gandler is certainly worthy of study by anyone interested in this complex philosophical tradition, especially as it has been encountered and furthered by philosophers south of the U.S.–Mexican border." (Carlos Alberto Sánchez: [http://c.ymcdn.com/sites/www.apaonline.org/resource/collection/60044C96-F3E0-4049-BC5A-271C673FA1E5/HispanicV14n1.pdf ''From the editor.''] In: ''APA Newsletter on Hispanic/Latino Issues in Philosophy'', American Philosophical Association, University of Delaware, Newark, DE, vol. 14, no. 1, fall 2014, p. 1. {{ISSN|2155-9708}}.) Sánchez calls Gandler a ''exemplary, contemporary Latin American philosopher.''</ref> He worked also as translator of philosophical texts between Spanish and German and published texts on Today's Germany and the National Socialism.<ref>[http://www.jornada.unam.mx/2006/06/18/sem-stefan.html See for example: ''Alemania: antes y después de Shoah.'' In: La Jornada Semanal. Supplement of ''La Jornada''. Mexico City, no. 589, June 18, 2006, p. 5.]</ref> Gandler is working on a productive conceptual confrontation between the [[Critical theory]] of the [[Frankfurt School]] and its contemporary further developments in Latin America,<ref>Javier Laso: [http://www.frequency.com/video/palabra-suelta-entrevista-televisiva/16209794 ''Palabra Suelta. Entrevista con Stefan Gandler.''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160105044257/http://www.frequency.com/video/palabra-suelta-entrevista-televisiva/16209794 |date=2016-01-05 }} Interview in the public Ecuadorian Television Channel ECTV (Ecuador TV), July 14, 2010, 9:30pm to 10:15pm,.</ref> for example from the Ecuadorian-Mexican philosopher [[Bolívar Echeverría]],<ref>Michael Löwy: [http://www.jornada.unam.mx/2007/05/06/index.php?section=opinion&article=a04a1cul ''Adolfo Sánchez Vázquez y Bolívar Echeverría.''] In: ''La Jornada.'' Mexico City, may 6, 20007 p. 4a.</ref> trying to overcome the limitations of both: the philosophical [[Eurocentrism]] in the first case, and the reduced [[Critique of ideology]] in the second.<ref>Julio Boltvinik: [http://www.jornada.unam.mx/2007/09/28/index.php?section=opinion&article=032o1eco ''Gandler critica a Bolívar Echeverría. Se presentó en el FCE ''Marxismo crítico en México''.''] In: ''La Jornada.'' México, September 28, 2007, p. 32.</ref> In that context he uses also the non dogmatic interpretation of the works of [[Karl Marx]] made by the Spanish-Mexican philosopher [[Adolfo Sánchez Vázquez]],<ref>Arturo Jiménez: [http://www.jornada.unam.mx/2007/09/28/index.php?section=cultura&article=a06n1cul ''Reivindica estudioso el marxismo crítico de Sánchez Vázquez y Bolívar Echeverría.''] In: ''La Jornada.'' Mexico City, September 28, 2007, p. 6a.</ref> and that made by the [[Max Horkheimer|Horkheimer]]-successor [[Alfred Schmidt (philosopher)|Alfred Schmidt]].<ref>Jordi Magnet Colomer: [http://revistes.ub.edu/index.php/oximora/article/view/10258/13234 '' Fragmentos de Frankfurt. Ensayos sobre la Teoría crítica.''] In: ''Oxímora. Revista internacional de ética y política'', Barcelona, spring 2014, pp. 126-132, here: p. 127.</ref>
== Main Works ==
===Books=== * Wolfgang Pohrt, [[Klaus Bittermann]], Stefan Gandler et al., ''Gemeinsam sind wir unausstehlich. Die Wiedervereinigung und ihre Folgen.'' : ''For the prehistoric organism, see [[Tamga (genus)]]'' A '''tamga''' or '''tamgha''' "stamp, seal" ({{lang-mn|тамга}}, {{lang-otk|𐱃𐰢𐰍}} ''tamga''; {{lang-tr|damga}}; [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish:]] طمغا ) is an abstract [[Seal (emblem)|seal]] or [[Seal (emblem)|stamp]] used by [[Eurasian nomad]]ic peoples and by cultures influenced by them. The tamga was normally the emblem of a particular tribe, clan or family. They were common among the Eurasian nomads throughout Classical Antiquity and the Middle Ages (including [[Alans]], [[Mongols]], [[Sarmatians]], [[Scythians]] and [[Turkic peoples]]). Similar "tamga-like" symbols were sometimes adopted by sedentary peoples adjacent to the Pontic-Caspian steppe both in [[Eastern Europe]] and [[Central Asia]].Ottfried Neubecker. ''Heraldik''. Orbis, 2002; Brook 154; Franklin and Shepard 120-121; Pritsak 78-79. Archaeologists prize tamgas as a first-rate source for the study of present and extinct cultures.{{citation needed|date=October 2014}} ==Medieval tamgas== ===Mongol empire=== [[File:Member of Mongolian Association of Numismatics.png|thumb|Logo with the [[Xiongnu]] tamga; these five symbols were later used as the tamgas of [[Genghis Khan]] and his sons.]] [[File:Kaidu's tamga.png|thumb|Tamgha of [[Kaidu]], [[House of Ögedei]].]] Since the time when the ancients, including the [[Mongol]] nations have developed into relative groups, origins, and ethnic groups, the symbol and belief of a clan have emerged, and a custom to distinguish their origins and relatives have been established. Consequently, when labor distributions within clans began to develop and people started to manage an economy, various tamgas, drawings, notes and earmarks have been used as an identification sign for labor instruments and utilities as well as in domestication of animals. Every time the clan branched off due to internal clashes, the number of derivative tamghas gradually developed into personal, family, lineage, khans, and state tamghas. Those new tamghas were created through adding new markings on the original tamgha, in order to conserve the tradition. In the Mongol Empire a Tamgha was a seal placed on taxed items, and by extension, a tax on commerce.(and see Eastern Europe below) Christian, History of Russia, Central Asia and Mongolia, page 415 "Tamga" or "tamag" literally means a stamp or seal in the [[Mongolian language]]. Tamgas are also [[Livestock branding|stamped using hot irons]] on domesticated animals such as horses in present-day [[Mongolia]] and others to identify that the livestock belongs to a certain family while they graze during the day on their own. In this regard, each family has their own tamga markings for easier identification. Tamga marking in that case is not very elaborate and is just a curved iron differentiating from other families' tamgas. The [[President of Mongolia]] also passes the ''tamag'' "state seal" when he or she transitions the position to the new president. In the presidential case, the tamag or seal is a little more elaborate and is contained in a wooden box. ===Turkic peoples=== [[Image:Flag of the Crimean Tatar people.svg|thumb|Flag of the [[Crimean Tatars]], sporting the traditional tamğa.]] The Turks who remained pastoral nomad kings in eastern Anatolia and Iran however, continued to use their clan tamgas, and in fact they became high-strung nationalistic imagery. The [[Ak Koyunlu]] and [[Kara Koyunlu]], like many other royal dynasties in Eurasia, put their tamga on their flags and stamped their coinage with it. For those Turks who never left their homeland of [[Turkestan]] in the first place it remained and still is what it was originally, a cattle brand and clan identifier. Among modern [[Turkic peoples]], the tamga is a design identifying [[property]] or [[cattle]] belonging to a specific Turkic clan, usually as a [[livestock branding|cattle brand]] or [[seal (emblem)|stamp]]. When Turkish clans took over more [[Urban area|urban]] or [[rural area]]s, tamgas dropped out of use as [[pastoral]] ways of life became forgotten. This is most evident in the Turkish clans who took over western and eastern [[Anatolia]] following the [[Battle of Manzikert]]. The Turks who took over western Anatolia founded the [[Sultanate of Rûm]] and became Roman-style aristocrats. Most of them adopted the (at the time) Muslim symbol of the [[Seal of Solomon]] after the Sultanate disintegrated into a mass of feuding [[ghazi (warrior)|ghazi]] states (see [[Isfendiyarids]], [[Karamanids]]). Only the Ottoman ghazi state (later to become the [[Ottoman Empire]]) kept its [[Ottoman flag|tamga]], and this was highly stylized, so much so that the bow was stylized down eventually to a crescent moon. Tamgas of the twenty-two [[Oghuz Turks|Oghuz tribes]] according to [[Mahmud al-Kashgari]] in [[Dīwānu l-Luġat al-Turk]]:Kâşgarlı Mahmûd: Divânü Lugâti't-Türk, Kabalcı Yayınevi Publishing, p.354

==Eastern Europe == [[File:Tamga of Tiberius Julius Eupator.JPG|thumb|Tamga of the [[Bosporan Kingdom|Bosporan king]] [[Tiberius Julius Eupator]], crowned by two winged victories. The relief dates to the second century CE.]] In Russia, the term ''tamga'' (''тамга'') survived in state institution of border customs, with associated cluster of terms: ''tamozhnya'' (''таможня'', customs), ''tamozhennik'' (''таможенник'', customs officer), ''rastamozhit''' (''растаможить'', pay customs duties), derived from the use of tamga as a certificate of state. [[Columns of Gediminas]], an early coat of arms of Lithuania, may be a tamga. ==Islamic empires== [[File:Taj Mahal top of finial.jpg|thumb|Tamga of the [[Mughal Empire]] on top of the [[Taj Mahal]].]] In the late medieval [[Turco-Mongol]] states, the term ''tamga'' was used for any kind of official stamp or seal. This usage persisted in the early modern Islamic Empires ([[Ottoman Empire]], [[Mughal Empire]]), and in some of their modern successor states. In the [[Urdu]] language (which absorbed Turkic vocabulary), ''Tamgha'' is used as [[medal]]. [[Tamgha-i-Jurat]] is the fourth highest Military medal of [[Pakistan]]. It is admissible to all ranks for gallantry and distinguished services in combat. [[Tamgha-i-Imtiaz]] or Tamgha-e-Imtiaz ({{lang-ur|تمغہ امتیاز}}), which translates as "medal of excellence", is fourth highest honour given by the Government of Pakistan to both the military and civilians. [[Tamgha-i-Khidmat]] or Tamgha-e-Khidmat ({{lang-ur|تمغۂ خدمت}}), which translates as "medal of services", is seventh highest honour given by the Government of Pakistan to both the military and civilians. It is admissible to non-commissioned officers and other ranks for long meritorious or distinguished services of a non-operational nature. In [[Egypt]], the term ''damgha'' ({{lang-ar|دمغة}}) or ''tamgha'' ({{lang|ar|تمغة}}) is still used in two contexts. One is a tax or fee when dealing with the government. It is normally in the form of stamps that have to be purchased and affixed to government forms, such as a driver license or a registration deed for a contract. The term is derived from the Ottoman [[damga resmi]]. Another is a stamp put on every piece of jewelry made from gold or silver to indicate it is genuine, and not made of baser metals. ==See also== * [[House mark]] * [[Mon (emblem)]] * [[Siglas poveiras]] * [[Tughra]] ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== * Brook, Kevin Alan. {{distinguish|Engineering tolerance}} A '''tolerance interval''' is a [[statistical interval]] within which, with some confidence level, a specified proportion of a sampled population falls. "More specifically, a 100×p%/100×(1−α) tolerance interval provides limits within which at least a certain proportion (p) of the population falls with a given level of confidence (1−α)."D. S. Young (2010), Book Reviews: "Statistical Tolerance Regions: Theory, Applications, and Computation", TECHNOMETRICS, FEBRUARY 2010, VOL. 52, NO. 1, pp.143-144. "A (p, 1−α) tolerance interval (TI) based on a sample is constructed so that it would include at least a proportion p of the sampled population with confidence 1−α; such a TI is usually referred to as p-content − (1−α) coverage TI."Krishnamoorthy, K. and Lian, Xiaodong(2011) 'Closed-form approximate tolerance intervals for some general linear models and comparison studies', Journal of Statistical Computation and Simulation,, First published on: 13 June 2011 {{DOI|10.1080/00949655.2010.545061}} "A (p, 1−α) upper '''tolerance limit''' (TL) is simply an 1−α upper [[confidence limit]] for the 100 p [[percentile]] of the population." A tolerance interval can be seen as a statistical version of a [[probability interval]]. "In the parameters-known case, a 95% tolerance interval and a 95% [[prediction interval]] are the same."{{cite book|author=Thomas P. Ryan|title=Modern Engineering Statistics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aZn7XNphKcgC&pg=PA222|accessdate=22 February 2013|date=22 June 2007|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-0-470-12843-5|pages=222–}} If we knew a population's exact parameters, we would be able to compute a range within which a certain proportion of the population falls. For example, if we know a population is [[normal distribution|normally distributed]] with [[mean]] \mu and [[standard deviation]] \sigma, then the interval \mu \pm 1.96\sigma includes 95% of the population (1.96 is the [[z-score]] for 95% coverage of a normally distributed population). However, if we have only a sample from the population, we know only the [[sample mean]] \hat{\mu} and sample standard deviation \hat{\sigma}, which are only estimates of the true parameters. In that case, \hat{\mu} \pm 1.96\hat{\sigma} will not necessarily include 95% of the population, due to variance in these estimates. A tolerance interval bounds this variance by introducing a confidence level \gamma, which is the confidence with which this interval actually includes the specified proportion of the population. For a normally distributed population, a z-score can be transformed into a "''k'' factor" or '''tolerance factor'''{{cite web |title= Statistical interpretation of data — Part 6: Determination of statistical tolerance intervals |publisher= ISO 16269-6|year= 2005 |page= 64}} for a given \gamma via lookup tables or several approximation formulas.{{cite book | chapter = Tolerance intervals for a normal distribution | url = http://www.itl.nist.gov/div898/handbook/prc/section2/prc263.htm | title = Engineering Statistics Handbook | publisher = NIST/Sematech | year = 2010 | accessdate = 2011-08-26}} "As the degrees of freedom approach infinity, the prediction and tolerance intervals become equal."{{Cite journal | last1 = De Gryze | first1 = S. | last2 = Langhans | first2 = I. | last3 = Vandebroek | first3 = M. | doi = 10.1016/j.chemolab.2007.03.002 | title = Using the correct intervals for prediction: A tutorial on tolerance intervals for ordinary least-squares regression | journal = Chemometrics and Intelligent Laboratory Systems | volume = 87 | issue = 2 | pages = 147 | year = 2007 | pmid = | pmc = }} ==Formulas== {{expand section|with=mathematical equations|date=July 2014|discuss=Talk:Tolerance interval#Math?}} ===Normal case=== ==Relation to other intervals== {{Main|Interval estimation}} The tolerance interval is less widely known than the [[confidence interval]] and [[prediction interval]], a situation some educators have lamented, as it can lead to misuse of the other intervals where a tolerance interval is more appropriate.{{cite journal | author = Stephen B. Vardeman | title = What about the Other Intervals? | journal = The American Statistician | volume = 46 | issue = 3 | year = 1992 | pages = 193–197 | jstor = 2685212 | doi=10.2307/2685212}}{{cite web | author = Mark J. Nelson | title = You might want a tolerance interval | url = http://www.kmjn.org/notes/tolerance_intervals.html | date = 2011-08-14 | accessdate = 2011-08-26}} The tolerance interval differs from a [[confidence interval]] in that the confidence interval bounds a single-valued population parameter (the [[mean]] or the [[variance]], for example) with some confidence, while the tolerance interval bounds the range of data values that includes a specific proportion of the population. Whereas a confidence interval's size is entirely due to [[sampling error]], and will approach a zero-width interval at the true population parameter as sample size increases, a tolerance interval's size is due partly to sampling error and partly to actual variance in the population, and will approach the population's probability interval as sample size increases. The tolerance interval is related to a [[prediction interval]] in that both put bounds on variation in future samples. The prediction interval only bounds a single future sample, however, whereas a tolerance interval bounds the entire population (equivalently, an arbitrary sequence of future samples). In other words, a prediction interval covers a specified proportion of a population ''on average'', whereas a tolerance interval covers it ''with a certain confidence level'', making the tolerance interval more appropriate if a single interval is intended to bound multiple future samples.{{cite book | author = K. Krishnamoorthy| title = Statistical Tolerance Regions: Theory, Applications, and Computation | publisher = John Wiley and Sons | year = 2009 | isbn = 0-470-38026-8 | pages = 1–6}} ===Examples=== gives the following example:
So consider once again a proverbial [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|EPA]] [[Fuel economy in automobiles|mileage]] test scenario, in which several nominally identical autos of a particular model are tested to produce mileage figures y_1, y_2, ..., y_n. If such data are processed to produce a 95% confidence interval for the mean mileage of the model, it is, for example, possible to use it to project the mean or total gasoline consumption for the manufactured fleet of such autos over their first 5,000 miles of use. Such an interval, would however, not be of much help to a person renting one of these cars and wondering whether the (full) 10-gallon tank of gas will suffice to carry him the 350 miles to his destination. For that job, a prediction interval would be much more useful. (Consider the differing implications of being "95% sure" that \mu \ge 35 as opposed to being "95% sure" that y_{n+1} \ge 35.) But neither a confidence interval for \mu nor a prediction interval for a single additional mileage is exactly what is needed by a design engineer charged with determining how large a gas tank the model really needs to guarantee that 99% of the autos produced will have a 400-mile cruising range. What the engineer really needs is a tolerance interval for a fraction p = .99 of mileages of such autos.
Another example is given by:
The air lead levels were collected from n=15 different areas within the facility. It was noted that the log-transformed lead levels fitted a normal distribution well (that is, the data are from a [[lognormal distribution]]. Let \mu and \sigma^2, respectively, denote the population mean and variance for the log-transformed data. If X denotes the corresponding random variable, we thus have X \sim \mathcal{N}(\mu, \sigma^2). We note that exp(mu) is the median air lead level. A confidence interval for mu can be constructed the usual way, based on the [[Student's t-distribution|''t''-distribution]]; this in turn will provide a confidence interval for the median air lead level. If \bar{X} and S denote the sample mean and standard deviation of the log-transformed data for a sample of size n, a 95% confidence interval for mu is given by \bar{X} \pm t_{n-1,0.975} S / \sqrt(n), where t_{m,1-\alpha} denotes the 1-alpha quantile of a [[Student's t-distribution|''t''-distribution]] with m degrees of freedom. It may also be of interest to derive a 95% upper confidence bound for the median air lead level. Such a bound for mu is given by \bar{X} + t_{n-1,0.95} S / \sqrt{n}. Consequently, a 95% upper confidence bound for the median air lead is given by \exp{\left( \bar{X} + t_{n-1,0.95} S / \sqrt{n} \right)}. Now suppose we want to predict the air lead level at a particular area within the laboratory. A 95% upper prediction limit for the log-transformed lead level is given by \bar{X} + t_{n-1,0.95} S \sqrt{\left( 1 + 1/n \right)}. A two-sided prediction interval can be similarly computed. The meaning and interpretation of these intervals are well known. For example, if the confidence interval \bar{X} \pm t_{n-1,0.975} S / \sqrt{n} is computed repeatedly from independent samples, 95% of the intervals so computed will include the true value of \mu, in the long run. In other words, the interval is meant to provide information concerning the parameter \mu only. A prediction interval has a similar interpretation, and is meant to provide information concerning a single lead level only. Now suppose we want to use the sample to conclude whether or not at least 95% of the population lead levels are below a threshold. The confidence interval and prediction interval cannot answer this question, since the confidence interval is only for the median lead level, and the prediction interval is only for a single lead level. What is required is a tolerance interval; more specifically, an upper tolerance limit. The upper tolerance limit is to be computed subject to the condition that at least 95% of the population lead levels is below the limit, with a certain confidence level, say 99%.
==Calculation== One-sided normal tolerance intervals have an exact solution in terms of the sample mean and sample variance based on the [[Noncentral t-distribution|noncentral ''t''-distribution]]. Two-sided normal tolerance intervals can be obtained based on the [[noncentral chi-squared distribution]].{{cite journal| author=Derek S. Young| title=tolerance: An R Package for Estimating Tolerance Intervals| journal=Journal of Statistical Software|date=August 2010| volume=36| number=5| pages=1–39| issn=1548-7660| url=http://www.jstatsoft.org/v36/i05| accessdate=19 February 2013}}, p.23 ==See also== *[[Engineering tolerance]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book | author = K. Krishnamoorthy| title = Statistical Tolerance Regions: Theory, Applications, and Computation | publisher = John Wiley and Sons | year = 2009 | isbn = 0-470-38026-8}}; Chap. 1, "Preliminaries", is available at http://media.wiley.com/product_data/excerpt/68/04703802/0470380268.pdf * {{cite journal| author=Derek S. Young| title=tolerance: An R Package for Estimating Tolerance Intervals| journal=Journal of Statistical Software|date=August 2010| volume=36| number=5| pages=1–39| issn=1548-7660| url=http://www.jstatsoft.org/v36/i05| accessdate=19 February 2013}} * ISO 16269-6, Statistical interpretation of data, Part 6: Determination of statistical tolerance intervals, Technical Committee ISO/TC 69, Applications of statistical methods. Available at http://standardsproposals.bsigroup.com/home/getpdf/458 {{statistics|inference|collapsed}} [[Category:Engineering concepts]] [[Category:Statistical intervals]] [[Category:Statistical forecasting]]
